oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Young man (of the early race) who was changed into a porcupine. He is said to be the brother of the girl in the preceding legend. Remarks regarding the porcupine follow. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-13. 5023-5039, and 14. 5040-5054). A tale of the Early Race (or !khwe ||na ss'e !k'e) in which the brother of the maiden taken up in a whirlwind by the angry Rain is transformed into a Porcupine. Parents tell their children to avoid eating the back of the porcupine's neck and tail, because that is where the hail sits. Also about porcupines and the stars. 1) p.5022v: this story was told to Dia!kwain by his mother (=kamme-an), 2) p.5043v: what people call the place where they see the sun ('ostrich eye' or Ttoi tsa xau), 3) See also The maiden who was taken up in a whirlwind by the agency of the angry Rain and became a great snake, 4) This story is found in Books V-13 and V-14.
